spomeniks.title: Bihać (Бихаћ)
spomeniks.name: Garavice Memorial Park of the victims of Fascist Terror (Spomen-područje Garavice)

spomeniks.title: Petrova Gora
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Uprising of the People of Kordun and Banija (Spomenik ustanku naroda Banije i Korduna)
spomeniks.location: Petrova Gora National Park, just east of Vojnić, Croatia

stories.text: As this monument's form does not seem to be directly created or imbued with any specific symbolism in its general appearance, the personal emotions Bakić imbued in its creation was certainly significant, as he dedicated the monument to his four brothers, all of whom died at the Ustaše's Jadovno death camps in 1941.

The exterior of the building was not officially completed until October 4th, 1981, during which time it was inaugurated during a ceremony by the President of the Parliament of the SR of Croatia, Jure Bilić, which was attended by nearly 4,000 people.

With the onset of the Yugoslav Wars in the 1990s the monument at Petrova Gora fell into disrepair and was targeted and attacked by vandals. Over the subsequent decades it became completely defaced, looted and demolished, with all its historical artifacts and relics contained within its museum and archives being taken or destroyed.

What remains now is a hollow husk of a structure, being held up by a massive concrete skeleton. The majority of the stainless steel panels have been removed and/or stolen, while fallen pieces of rotted insulation are scattered around the entire monument, inside and out. The basement level is flooded and inhabited by animals. Meanwhile, the elevator-shafts lay wide-open, exposing an eerie pitch-black void. The front of the building is gated and fenced in, however, holes have been made in the fences to allow entrance to the structure.

spomeniks.title: Ilirska Bistrica
spomeniks.name: Monument on Freedom Hill (Hrib Svobode)

spomeniks.title: Dražgoše
spomeniks.name: Monument Cankar Battalion in Dražgoše (Spomenik Cankarjevega bataljona v Dražgošah)

spomeniks.title: Sisak
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Detachment in Brezovica Forest (Brezovica Spomen-Park)
spomeniks.location: Novo Selo Palanječko, Croatia (small village just east of Sisak)

spomeniks.title: Podgarić
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Revolution of the People of Moslavina (Spomenik Revolucije Naroda Moslavine)

stories.text: According to the designer, Dušan Džamonja, the primary intention of the monument was to represent the 'wings of victory' overcoming death and defeat, an overt allusion to the Partisan rebel's conquest over the invading Axis occupiers. The 'wings' of the sculpture are asymmetrical, with one wing having two edges, while the other has three. This imbalance gives the sculpture a dynamic shape, as if the wings are in motion or as if it a bird preparing to take flight.

As a consequence of the significant Partisan efforts towards uprising and opposition against occupying Ustaše forces in Podgarić, local government and regional veteran groups there made plans in the mid-1960s for the construction of a spomenik complex to recognize these achievements.

Currently, this memorial complex here at Podgarić is in reasonably good condition, with there being few signs of serious or extensive damage or deterioration of the monument's structure. While there is no signage or advertising directing visitors from the road to the monument, there seems to be some degree of maintenance and upkeep going on.

Meanwhile, in the years since the abstract Yugoslav monuments reached global popularity in the early 2010s, the sculpture here at Podgarić has often stood among those whose adventurous form foreign audiences were most captivated and inspired by. This has led to many internet-based digital artists using images of the monument as a basis for their digital artwork.

spomeniks.title: Jasenovac
spomeniks.name: Flower Monument (Cvjetni spomenik), but commonly referred to as 'Stone Flower' (Kameni Cvijet)

spomeniks.title: Vukovar
spomeniks.name: Dudik Memorial Park (Spomen-park Dudik)

spomeniks.title: Kozara (Козара)
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Revolution (Spomenik Revoluciji/Споменик Револуцији)
spomeniks.location: Mrakovica area of Kozara National Park, Republic of Srpska, Bosnia

spomeniks.title: Sanski Most
spomeniks.name: Šušnjar Memorial Complex (Спомен-подручје Шушњар/Spomen Groblje Šušnjar)
spomeniks.location: Sanski Most, FBiH, Bosnia and Herzegovina

spomeniks.title: Knin
spomeniks.name: Monument to Knin Liberators (Spomenik oslobodiocima Knina)

spomeniks.title: Vodice
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen Soldiers of WWII from Vodice

spomeniks.title: Košute
spomeniks.name: Monument to the 1st Split Partisan Detachment

stories.text: This monument at Košute was built to commemorate the 1st Split Partisan detachment, a squad of mostly inexperienced young men from Split, Croatia who, in August 1941, decided to take up arms against the occupying Axis forces, just months after Dalmatia was annexed by the invading Italian forces.

The primary element of the spomenik was a 17m tall triple-obelisk balanced on a tripod, set upon bare rock. During the years of Yugoslavia, the memorial complex was a significant cultural and historic landmark for tourists, veterans and locals wishing to pay respects to the memory of those who were lost.

The monument here at Košute became a symbol of 'the old system' for many nationalistic Croatians. At some point around August 21st/22nd of 1992, the monument was laden with explosives, brought to the ground and destroyed.

I was unable to establish that the site receives any nature of protection status or official historical recognition extended to the site by the Croatian government on either the local, regional or national level.  The only other observable presence of those visiting the monument, other than those wishing to deface it, were the goats and other animals that herders continually using the graze the hillsides.

spomeniks.title: Podgora
spomeniks.name: Seagull Wings Monument (Spomenik Galebova krila)

spomeniks.title: Mostar
spomeniks.name: Partisan Memorial Cemetery in Mostar (Partizansko Groblje u Mostaru) (aka: Partiza)

spomeniks.title: Gornji Jelovac
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen Soldiers of the Battle of Kozara
spomeniks.location: Gornji Jelovac, Republic of Srpska, Bosnia & Herzegovina

spomeniks.title: Zenica
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen Partisan Detachment from Zenica
materials: steel frame covered with aluminum plates

spomeniks.title: Novi Travnik
spomeniks.name: Necropolis for the Victims of Fascism (Nekropola žrtvama fašizma) or Monument on Smrike (Spomenik na Smrika)
spomeniks.location: Čamića Brdo, a hill just NE of Novi Travnik, FBiH, Bosnia & Herzegovina

spomeniks.title: Vogošća
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen Fighters of People's Liberation War (Spomenik i spomen-kosturnica borcima NOR-a)
spomeniks.location: on Džindino Hill, Vogošća, FBiH, Bosnia & Herzegovina

spomeniks.title: Tjentište (Тјентиште)
spomeniks.name: The Battle of Sutjeska Memorial Monument Complex in the Valley of Heroes
spomeniks.location: Tjentište, Republic of Srpska, Bosnia & Hercegovina

stories.text: In early June of 1943, the Partisans were subsequently boxed in and trapped within Axis lines on Vučevo Mountain on the east Sutjeska River valley, near the small village of Tjentište. As a result, a massive battle between the two sides ensued in what today is known as the 'Battle of Sutjeska' (Bitka na Sutjesci). Despite this hopeless seeming situation, Tito orchestrated a daring move where, starting on the morning of June 9th, he ordered Partisan units to begin breaking west across the open valley and over the river. Some of the Partisans were surprisingly successful in breaking the German lines, at which point they headed up a steep ravine of Ozren Mountain and were then able to break north through German lines and escape past Goražde through the mountains into eastern Bosnia.

The sculpture is positioned upon a man-made hillside which situates it in such a way as that the monument can be dramatically seen from across nearly the entire Sutjeska Valley. This placement creates a situation where the monument acts symbolically and physically as both a guardian over the valley, but also as a sort of 'receiver' of the souls from the battlefield's fallen fighters.

The idea is that of breakthrough and victory, the two blocks with the figures inside represent the breaking of the circle created around the Partisan forces. The opening takes the shape of the fighters, very stylized, in an architectonic manner, and simple geometric forms to emphasize the presence of men of the individual fighters in the columns, because it is those columns of men that made the breakthrough at Sutjeska possible.

Honorific flowers, candles and wreaths left at this complex is common... existing as clear evidence of locals paying tribute to the site. In fact, in recent years, commemorative and remembrance ceremonies have been a regular occurrence here at Tjentište.

spomeniks.title: Kadinjača (Кадињача)
spomeniks.name: Kadinjača Memorial Complex (Спомен комплекс Кадињача)

spomeniks.location: On the slopes of Jelica Mountiain in Čačak, Serbia

spomeniks.location: At 'Trg Svobode' (Freedom Square) in Maribor, Slovenia

spomeniks.title: Ostra (остра)

spomeniks.title: Kragujevac (Крагујевац)
spomeniks.name: Šumarice Memorial Park (aka: Memorial Park October in Kragujevac/Спомен-парк Крагујевачки октобар)

spomeniks.title: Kosmaj (Космај)
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen Soldiers of the Kosmaj Detachment (Споменик борцима Космајског одреда)
spomeniks.location: Kosmaj Mountain Park, Serbia (just south of Belgrade near Sopot)

spomeniks.title: Nikšić (Никшић)
spomeniks.name: Monument to Fallen Fighters of WWII (Spomenik Palim Borcima U Drugom Svjetskom Ratu)

spomeniks.title: Sinj
spomeniks.name: Memorial & Crypt to the Battle of the 1st Split Partisan Unit (Spomenik i kosturnica boraca Prvog splitskog partizanskog odreda)

spomeniks.title: Avala (Авала)
spomeniks.name: Soviet War Veterans Monument (Spomenik sovjetskim ratnim veteranima/Споменик совјетским ратним ветеранима)
spomeniks.location: Near Pinosava village on Mt. Avala, just south of Belgrade, Serbia

spomeniks.title: Požarevac
spomeniks.name: "The Star (Zvezda / звезда)" at the Memorial Park Čačalica (Спомен парк Чачалица)

spomeniks.title: Niš (Ниш)
spomeniks.name: Bubanj Memorial Park, "The Three Fists" (Спомен-парк Бубањ)

stories.text: This spomenik complex at Niš commemorates the +10,000 Serbian, Jew and Roma that were executed at this site (a small forested hill just southwest of Niš) from February 1942 to September 1944 by the Nazi occupiers. Niš was finally liberated by Partisans and the Bulgarian Army on October 14th, 1944, when the last remnants of the 7th German SS Division were driven out of the city.

Firstly, the three stylized-fist monoliths at the center of the memorial complex are of three different sizes, with the different sizes representing not only the fact that men, women and children were all brutally executed at this site, but also the fact that entire families together were killed here. Yet another interpretation of the symbolism of the three fists is that they represent they three primary ethnic groups that were killed at the site: Serbs, Jews and Roma.

Carved onto the wall on its right end is a verse from Niš poet Ivan Vučković (Slide 2), which, roughly translated from Serbian to English, reads as: "From the blood of communists and patriots, fists were born: Fists of rebellion and warning, Fists of revolution, Fists of freedom. We were shot, but never killed and never subdued. We crushed the darkness, and paved the way for the sun."

As this monument complex is also used as an active city park, it can see hundreds of visitors a day. There are significant annual ceremonies held at the monument on October 14th (Niš Liberation Day) as well as on May 6th (Djurdjevdan - St George's Day), both of which are generally attended by hundreds of local citizens.

spomeniks.title: Popina (Попина)
spomeniks.name: Popina Monument Park ('Mausoleum to the Fallen Insurgents'; "The Sniper")

spomeniks.title: Kruševac (Крушевац)

spomeniks.location: On Bagdala Hill in Kruševac, Serbia

spomeniks.location: On Partisan Hill in Mitrovica, Kosovo* (aka: Kosovska Mitrovica) (formerly Titova Mitrovica, 1980-1991)

spomeniks.title: Štip (Штип)
spomeniks.name: 'Partisan's Necropolis' (Партизанската некропола) or 'Memorial to Fallen Fighters of the Revolution'

spomeniks.title: Gevgelija (Гевгелија)
spomeniks.name: Monument to Freedom or 'The Flower of Freedom" (Цветот на слободата)
spomeniks.location: On Mrzenski Hill in Gevgelija, Macedonia

spomeniks.title: Botun (Ботун)
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Uprising at Debarca

spomeniks.title: Podhum
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Victims of Fascism (Spomenik Podhumskim žrtvama)

stories.text: This memorial complex at Podhum commemorates the victims which were executed by Axis Italian occupational forces during the National Liberation War (WWII). Documents indicate that upwards of 91 people from the area were executed in these reprisal killings, while nearly 1000 additional residents being sent off to Italian concentration camps.
The bulge shapes which make up the sculpture, of which there are 91, are said to be 'petals' of the flower representing each of the 91 victims who were executed at the site.

These walls softly encompass the place of death, and through the two passageways this terrible place communicates with the fields and the mountains. Contrasting with the gray stone walls are white plates bearing the names of the slain, and the rows of fragmented white stacks function as the headstones of the fallen villagers of Podhum.

In a 2018 ceremony commemorating 76 years since the massacre, head of the municipality of Čavle, Ivana Cvitan Polić, stated that she felt that all schools in the region should include a visit to the Podhum monument in their curriculum.

spomeniks.title: Kamenska
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Revolutionary Victory of the People of Slavonia (Spomenik pobjedi revolucije naroda Slavonije)
spomeniks.location: On Blažuj Hill in Kamenska, Croatia

stories.text: Challenges were faced finding contractors to build the structure, as something of its scale had never been attempted. Finally, the Zagreb contracting firm "Industromontaža" took up the challenge to construct the monument, aided by the Požega construction company "Pioneer"

In late February 1992, it is alleged this Croatian army brigade made several attempts to destroy the Kamenska monument with explosives, with these efforts eventually being successful with their third attempt on February 21st.  Reportedly, its strong and resilient construction resulted in the initial bombing attempts failing until successive attacks created weaknesses within the structure.

Some years after the destruction of the spomenik, all remnants and ruins of it were cleared and removed by locals, as the stainless-steel it was made from was extremely valuable, with much of it reportedly being used to make pots and pans.
This spomenik was one among many destroyed across Croatia during the wave of nationalism experienced in the early 1990s after Croatian independence.

spomeniks.title: Korenica
spomeniks.name: Central Monument of the White Streams (Bijeli Potoci) - Kamensko Memorial Area
spomeniks.location: ~18km SE of Korenica, Croatia (formerly Titova Korenica)

spomeniks.title: Veles (Велес)

spomeniks.title: Makarska

spomeniks.location: On Glavica Hill in Makarska, Croatia

spomeniks.title: Prilep (Прилеп)
spomeniks.name: Burial Mound of the Unbeaten (Могила на непобедените) or Partisan Necropolis
spomeniks.location: Park of the Revolution (aka: Mound Park) in Prilep, Macedonia
spomeniks.city: Park of the Revolution (aka: Mound Park) in Prilep

spomeniks.title: Makljen
spomeniks.name: "Poet (Pjesnik)" or "The Fist (Pesnica)" or "Monument to the Battle of the Wounded"
spomeniks.location: On Mt. Makljen, FBiH, Bosnia & Herzegovina

spomeniks.title: Zlatibor (Златибoр)
spomeniks.name: Monument on Šumatno Hill or Monument to the Executed Partisans (Споменик стрељаним партизанима)

spomeniks.title: Dotrščina
spomeniks.name: Dotrščina Memorial Park (Spomen-područje Dotrščina)

spomeniks.title: Slabinja
spomeniks.name: Monument to Fallen Fighters and Victims of Fascism from Slabinja

stories.text: The town of Slabinja fell under the military administration their NDH nationalist Ustaše militiamen. A campaign of war and terror was waged against the town by the Ustaše, as many of its residents were of ethnic-Serb descent, who the NDH wished to specifically expel or liquidate from its borders.

The monument was symbolically unveiled to the public on May 30th, 1981, which is not only the day of the 40th anniversary of the Yugoslavian people's uprising against oppression, but it is also the same month in which the town was finally liberated from Axis forces in 1945.

on the central stainless steel spire of the Slabinja memorial sculpture, the names and ages of exactly 547 fallen victims from the surrounding region of Banovia region, which was heavily impacted during WWII, are directly inscribed.

The state of the small spomenik complex here in Slabinja, Croatia is somewhat poor. While the landscaping and grounds in the vicinity of the complex are in reasonable order, this is more than likely due to the fact that the memorial is located in the center of the village adjacent to a children's playground, and less so to do with efforts to maintain or preserve the memorial.

spomeniks.location: On Šobić Hill in Drvar, FBiH, Bosnia & Herzegovina (previously 'Titov Drvar')

spomeniks.title: Jajinci (Јајинци)

spomeniks.title: Jasenica
spomeniks.name: Podgrmeč Museum and Memorial Fountain (Muzej Podgrmeč i spomen-fontana)

spomeniks.title: Mirna
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Fallen on Roja Hill (Spomenik padlim na Rojah)

spomeniks.title: Pleso
spomeniks.name: 'Broken Ring' (Probijanje obruča)

stories.text: This monument at the spomenik complex in Pleso area of Zagreb, Croatia commemorates the acts of sabotage committed by Partisan units on Axis controlled airports in the Zagreb area during WWII, while it also commemorates the liberation of Zagreb in 1945.

The shape of the memorial sculpture here at Pleso is a deliberate reference to the Yugoslav Army breaking the Ustaše and German defensive ring around the city of Zagreb in 1945, an event which subsequently led to the liberation of Zagreb from those Axis powers. The form of this abstract concrete sculpture consists of a standing squared-off tapering ring, with the ring broken at the top and offset roughly 1-2m.

From 1991 to 1995, the city of Zagreb was significantly affected by the conflicts and fighting during the Yugoslav Wars and the Croatian War of Independence. In 1997, a small plaque was added to the Pleso spomenik to commemorate two local fighters from Pleso who died during that war.

Monument for the village of Pleso whose heroes died in the People's Liberation battle for Yugoslavia, 1941-1945. For 35 years after the attack by the Turpolje Partisan Unit on the Pleso and Kurilovec airport, this monument symbolizes the breaking of the enemy's ring and is made for the city's government, alliance fighters for the People's Liberation fighters and the people of Velika Gorica and the people of Pleso.

spomeniks.title: Andrijevica (Андријевица)
spomeniks.name: Monument Park Knjaževac (Spomen-Park Knjaževac/Спомен-парк Књажевац)

spomeniks.title: Draginac (Драгинац)
spomeniks.name: Monument & Crypt to the Executed Victims of Draginac (Споменик са костурницом стрељаних жртава у Драгинцу)

spomeniks.title: Vođenica
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Vođenica Company

spomeniks.title: Glamoč

spomeniks.title: Brezovica (Брезовица)
spomeniks.name: Monument to the Šar Mountains Partisan Unit (споменик шарпланински Партизански одреда)

spomeniks.title: Landovicë (Љандовица)
spomeniks.name: Monument to Boro Vukmirović and Ramiz Sadiku

spomeniks.title: Brzeće (Брзеће)
spomeniks.name: Mramor Monument (Spomenik Na Mramoru/Споменик на Мрамору)

spomeniks.title: Begunje
spomeniks.name: Hostage's Cemetery (Grobišče Talcev)

spomeniks.title: Zaječar (Зајечар)
spomeniks.name: 'The Gallows (Vešala/Вешала)' or 'Monument to the Fallen in the Liberation War and the Victims of Fascist Terror'

spomeniks.title: Vranjske Njive
spomeniks.name: 'The Fork' (Виљушка) or 'The Monument to Hanged Patriots' (Споменик Обешеним патриотама)
spomeniks.location: Vranjske Njive, Montenegro, village just north of Podgorica

spomeniks.title: Gligino Brdo (Глигино Брдо)
spomeniks.name: Freedom Hill Monument
spomeniks.location: On Gligino Hill, just east of Dobrljin, Republic of Srpska, Bosnia & Herzegovina

stories.text: This spomenik complex on Gligino Hill (Gligino Brdo/Глигино Брдо) commemorates this location as the spot of the region's initial uprising efforts and organization by Partisan rebels during July of 1941.

During my research, I found very little to nothing about the planning, design and construction of this spomenik complex here at Gligino Brdo. While I was I not able to find the year this memorial was unveiled to the public, I was however able to discover that the artist who designed this monument was Banja Luka sculptor Ahmed Bešić.

Just a few meters south of the central memorial sculpture there is one small engraved marble plaque: At this place, on the 31st of July, 1941, movements were made towards uprising. We leave the world for a better sunrise. The big light on this hill shines love onto this country. Life and death have changed the name of this hill to 'Freedom Hill'.

Today, this spomenik complex at Gligino Brdo sits completely neglected and abandoned. There are no signs that any nature of maintenance or stewardship is undertaken to protect or preserve the complex, nor do there seem to be any indications that commemorative or remembrance events are held here any longer.
